unnormalised: India, a land of chaotic beauty and traffic that could make a saint swear, also boasts a surprisingly scenic coastline. Forget those perilous auto-rickshaw rides; let's talk Indian seaways, where the only thing getting honked at are probably dolphins. Who knew?
normalised: India, a land of chaotic beauty and traffic that could make a saint swear, also boasts a surprisingly scenic coastline. Forget those perilous auto-rickshaw rides; let's talk Indian seaways, where the only thing getting honked at are probably dolphins. Who knew?

unnormalised: Forget the usual Goa beach trip for a sec. Think beyond the sunburns and questionable cocktails. We're diving headfirst (metaphorically, maybe wear a life jacket) into the world of coastal cruises. From Mumbai to Goa, you can ditch the 12-hour bus ride (and the questionable aromas emanating from your fellow passengers) for a leisurely cruise, lasting approx. 16 hrs. Luxury, my friend, luxury! Just imagine sipping chai on the deck while watching the Arabian Sea do its thing. No auto-rickshaw drivers trying to rip you off, just the gentle rocking of the boat and the faint sound of Bollywood tunes (likely played by someone's enthusiastic uncle).

unnormalised: Now, some may scoff and say, "Cruises? So boring!" To them, I say: Have you ever tried explaining Indian wedding logistics to a foreigner? Now *that's* boring. Cruises are the epitome of relaxation. You can eat your weight in buffet food, gamble away your inheritance (responsibly, of course), and attend themed parties where the theme is often "slightly tipsy". The ships are usually tricked out with pools, spas, and enough entertainment to distract you from the fact that you are, in fact, on a giant floating metal box.

unnormalised: And the destinations! From the vibrant markets of Kochi to the Portuguese-infused charm of Goa, each port is an adventure in itself. Just be prepared for the inevitable haggling with vendors. Remember, "Rs. 500" is always negotiable. Always. You might even spot some rare marine life along the way. Keep an eye out for the elusive pink dolphin of the Ganges, or maybe just a bunch of seagulls fighting over a chip packet. Either way, it's entertainment!

unnormalised: Let's talk rupees, shall we? A typical cruise package from Mumbai to Goa can set you back anywhere from ₹15,000 to ₹50,000 per person, depending on the cabin and the level of... let's call it "extravaganza." Think of it as an investment in your sanity. Compared to the cost of therapy after battling Mumbai traffic for a week, it's practically a steal. Plus, you get to tell all your friends you went on a cruise. Instant social media gold!

unnormalised: The best time to set sail is usually between Oct and May. Avoid the monsoon season unless you enjoy the thrill of potentially becoming a real-life pirate (disclaimer: probably not a real pirate, just a very wet tourist). The weather is usually pleasant, the seas are relatively calm, and the sunsets are guaranteed to make you feel all kinds of philosophical. You might even question your life choices while contemplating the vastness of the ocean. But hey, that's what cruises are for, right?

unnormalised: So, the next time you're planning a getaway, consider ditching the crowded trains and overpriced flights. Embrace the slow life, embrace the sea, embrace the sheer absurdity of being on a giant floating palace in the Indian Ocean. Who knows, you might even discover your inner sailor. Or, at the very least, get a decent tan. Either way, it's a win-win. And remember, pack your sunscreen, your sense of humor, and maybe a bottle of antacids. Just in case. Fair winds and following seas, my friends!
